So it would be an embedded webserver that does what without D-Bus? Can you talk more about the use cases here?

Yeah, I should add more details here, but this revolved around a discussion around OCP IMA, which aims to make an on-host redfish webserver that can publish telemetry data either in-band, or push it to the bmc.

https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1v93e-zNcn3cwCHdO3uEBv41Fa_K9uskI/edit#slide=id.p1


ACK.  Will try to get more details in the commit message.
above doc URL requesting password

Shoot;  It's an OCP document, I think I linked the one that requires an OCP login.

Here's the public youtube for the presentation by one of my colleagues, George.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o8XoW8u-qVI

So this OCP IMA is a proposed project for an inline management agent not related at all to the Linux integrity management architecture that has used the IMA acronym since at least 2009.

not that I object to the patch.  

Do they intend to offer more than telemetry?    Things like storage or network?   How will it get it's data model to export without dbus?

> So this OCP IMA is a proposed project for an inline management agent not related at all to the Linux integrity management architecture that has used the IMA acronym since at least 2009.

Correct..... I didn't name it 😊

> 
> not that I object to the patch.  
> 
> Do they intend to offer more than telemetry?    Things like storage or network?   How will it get it's data model to export without dbus?

Probably better answered in the OCP forums, but the short version is that sysfs (or windows COM APIs) gives quite a bit of telemetry and control that we would want to model in redfish, and make available out of band.  The theory is that it would get it directly from sysfs.

Okay, so this is trying to make this work with service root. How does other redfish resources work?

In each route that is supported by both is there a
#ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_REDFISH_DBUS 

<call dbus>

#else 

<call sysfs>

#endif

> Okay, so this is trying to make this work with service root. How does other redfish resources work?

In the context of this patch, they don't.  This is attempting to make a reasonably reviewable patchset for something complicated.  In the future, I'm thinking there will be other backends with ifdefs like Redfish_<backend name>, but I'm open to other options.

I also suspect that in the future, backends won't share serviceroot, and would' implement their own based on their own use cases.

> 
> In each route that is supported by both is there a
> #ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_REDFISH_DBUS 
> 
> <call dbus>
> 
> #else 
> 
> <call sysfs>
> 
> #endif

I'm thinking each use case would have its own RequestRoutes call, so it would look like

#ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_REDFISH_DBUS
redfish_dbus::requestAccountServiceRoutes
#endif

#ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_SYSFS
redfish_dbus::requestAccoutServiceRoutes
#endif
I thought we moved the opposite way?

We did......  but I'm not sure that was the right thing to do, hence why I kinda stopped the migration halfway through.

There's a desire to be able to completely remove dependencies (dbus/sdbusplus in this case), and to do that, some level of ifdef is going to be required.  The assumption is that when this happens, the OCP team would have it's own CI to make sure that we're not breaking cross-system builds, so we wouldn't regress to what we had before (each option compiled differently and broke often dependent on configure options).


This is definitely half baked, but I wanted to get the idea out early in the process to see what peoples thoughts are.

if I moved the #ifdef BMCWEB_ENABLE_DBUS_REST into the individual header files, would that be better?  Trying to think of solutions.

This is the opposite we've been moving, but if a user doesn't link in sdbusplus, I'm not sure what options there are aside from completely removing the code.  Open to suggestions here.
this should be the dbus async_resolver.
whitespace error.
Done
This probably needs to be abstracted into some kind of "init module" interface.
Done

This adds a lot of ifdefs to bmcweb. I am concerned about the support. I think this needs a larger discussion.😬
What does bmcweb do?
Should bmcweb be targeted for applications outside openbmc and therefore, should we support a non-dbus use case?
How do we ensure this doesn't break this new non-dbus use case? How does an openbmc developer test this use case? In June 2022, you mentioned, "OCP team would have it's own CI to make sure that we're not breaking cross-system builds" - is that still planned? It would be exciting to see bmcweb used outside openbmc, bringing in more users and hopefully more developers/reviewers but I am worried about this slowing down bmcweb development

> This adds a lot of ifdefs to bmcweb.

Open to other options if there's a better design pattern.

> I am concerned about the support. I think this needs a larger discussion.😬

Happy to have it.

> What does bmcweb do?
> Should bmcweb be targeted for applications outside openbmc and therefore, should we support a non-dbus use case?

Ironically, bmcweb was originally targetted for non-OpenBMC use cases.  OpenBMC was added later.

> How do we ensure this doesn't break this new non-dbus use case?

Testing, but today, we don't do much verification that we don't break the dbus use case, so I'm not sure this is really a change.

> How does an openbmc developer test this use case?

I'm not sure why that matters?  Each side will do their testing and integration.

> In June 2022, you mentioned, "OCP team would have it's own CI to make sure that we're not breaking cross-system builds" - is that still planned?

Yep.

> It would be exciting to see bmcweb used outside openbmc, bringing in more users and hopefully more developers/reviewers but I am worried about this slowing down bmcweb development

Can you say more about this?  How do you think it will slow down bmcweb development?  Is it just the ifdefs?  Or something more?

> How do you think it will slow down bmcweb development?

By verifying this use case doesn't get broke. The more ifdefs the more likely something gets broke.

By that argument we shouldn't accept any ifdefs, and by extension of the compatibility guarantees, whomever checks in code first should allow their behavior to be in bmcweb forever without ever being replaced.  I realize that's taking your statement to an extreme, but it's what I think about often, that if we had a no ifdef policy 4 years ago, things like the thermal subsystem option, the dbus log server option, and others would likely have not been allowed.

I'm open to options other than ifdefs/contexpr configs if there's a better way to manage this, but the argument that we can't use ifdefs to control behavior because it'll slow down development I question heavily.  Ifdefs IMO speed up development, because we can accept features that maybe aren't use-case-complete, aren't secure for production usages, or aren't useful to a majority of users, which helps folks to fork less.

FWIW, this patchset got revived because someone is about to fork bmcweb to do exactly what this patchset is doing.  I think ifdefs can keep the development more localized and get more reviewers on the core components, that might not care about the dbus aspects.  At a fundamental level I think ifdefs are better than forking.
if disabled this would use sysfs for certain redfish resources?
if disabled it would use nothing for redfish resources (except for sockets).  The application would be standalone.  The theory being that you could add whatever logic you needed.

So this is a prototype to get the service root working without d-bus? The service root doesn't have any D-Bus calls. 
But to get something like https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/7a696974d7a987e3eb135a6cbad0a4ace8d109d2/redfish-core/lib/account_service.hpp#L2267 isn't that going to require a bunch of ifdefs ?

> So this is a prototype to get the service root working without d-bus? The service root doesn't have any D-Bus calls. 

Yep.

> But to get something like https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/7a696974d7a987e3eb135a6cbad0a4ace8d109d2/redfish-core/lib/account_service.hpp#L2267 isn't that going to require a bunch of ifdefs ?

My thinking is you'd set up another BMCWEB_ROUTE() for whatever your backend does.  AccountService is a little weird because it's partially in bmcweb and partially in dbus.  That needs more thought.
